Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Polymer Cross-Linked Aerogels for Their Strength and Energy Absorption in Seismic Retrofit of RC Structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objectives of this award are to study the effectiveness of polymer cross-linked aerogel -- a nano-encapsulated material with polymer coated nanoparticles -- in a damping-enhanced strengthening (DES) system for seismic retrofit and protection of reinforced concrete structures and to develop design guidelines for the use of this system in performance-based design of these structures. The DES system integrates the two attributes of strengthening and damping which are often used separately. The study will characterize the strength and energy absorption abilities of the aerogel, create a compact DES protective system with optimized damping and strengthening attributes using aerogel, and develop methods for performance based design of structures with the DES systems under multiple earthquakes of varying magnitudes. The DES system will be numerically modeled to study its performance in seismic retrofit of bridges. Deliverables include aerogel material performance specifications, characterization of the interfacial behaviors between retrofitting system and existing structure, fabrication and testing of the systems to demonstrate its effectiveness, modeling, analysis and design tools with DES systems, and engineering student education.

The results of this research will provide an opportunity to create compact, cost-effective engineering systems that enable the performance-based design of critical infrastructures with an optimal use of both damping and strengthening materials. Example applications include the seismic retrofit of buildings and bridges with optimized performance under different earthquakes and multiple performance objectives. The DES systems offer the advantages of being flame retardant and impact resistant and can be used in other civil and mechanical engineering applications. The research results will be disseminated to allow the implementation of a prototype DES system that has increased design flexibility, reduced cost, and reduced weight. Graduate engineering students will benefit through classroom instruction and involvement in the research. K-12 students will be engaged to provide them firsthand experience through demonstration projects.

Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

Performance_Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to explore, develop, and apply novel damping-enhanced or hybrid strengthening technologies for the seismic retrofit/repair of reinforced concrete (RC) columns and bridges under earthquake excitations with various intensities. An aerogel (foam) or viscoelastic (VE) layer is integrated into a multi-layer sandwiched system of a polyvinyl-chloride (PVC) tube and fiber reinforced polymer (FRP) sheets. The aerogel/viscoelastic material is used for energy dissipation/impact attenuation while the PVC or FRP layers restrain the lateral expansion of RC columns under axial loads. The performances of the novel technologies are compared with those of FRP wrapping alone and a prestressed thin steel sheet wrapping. The seismic performance of RC columns is translated into the system behavior of a three-span girder bridge with RC columns.

Intellectual Merits

This project enabled the exploration of several new concepts and methods over the project period. First, polyurea and polyurethane xerogels were characterized as a component of a sandwiched FRP wrapping system for concrete confinement. The xerogels revealed excellent energy-absorbing ability, significantly contributing the increased ductility of concrete confined by the sandwiched FRP system. Second, a framework of computational aerogels was developed to potentially allow the design of engineered nanomaterials in the future. A multi-scale united atom model was introduced to simulate the molecular dynamics of aerogels that were formed following a hierarchical, self-assembling process of aerogels. Third, a ductile and corrosion-free design concept of confined concrete-filled polyvinyl-chloride tubular columns was explored and developed. Confinement was provided with the use of a PVC tube and FRP wrappings or FRP with a sandwiched layer of foam to enhance impact energy reduction due to potential FRP rupture and PVC fracture. The confined columns can significantly enhance strength over the columns strengthened with conventional techniques. Fourth, a cushioning foam layer was introduced between FRP layers and PVC to effectively lessen the brittleness of FRP rupture in seismic regions. Without compressible foam, the confined cylinders experienced brittle failures upon FRP rupture and immediately-followed PVC fracture due to sudden transfer in confining pressure. With compressible foam, the confined cylinders can combine the strength of FRP wrapped cylinders and the ductility of concrete-filled PVC tubular cylinders. Fifth, a hybrid jacket of a thin steel sheet confined by prestressing strands was proposed for a rapid repair of seismically damaged concrete columns for bridge safety. While the prestressing strands can prevent buckling of the confining steel sheet, the steel sheet can in turn prevent the prestressing strands from cutting into concrete column. The hybrid jacketing concept was validated with testing of a large-scale RC column with lap splice deficiency, and proved effective in restoring structural behavior of the damaged column to prevent bridge collapse. Sixth, the effect of various hybrid jacketing techniques on the post-aftershock performance of the bridges that damaged during the main shock was investigated under near- and far-field ground motions. Seventh and lastly, the damping-enhanced strengthening concept was applied to a three-span continuous girder bridge for its performance under weak, moderate, and strong earthquakes. While damping alone cannot meet the performance requirement under strong earthquakes and FRP strengthening alone cannot meet the performance under weak earthquakes, their integration in the damping-enhanced strengthening scheme can provide satisfactory and nearly normalized performances under both weak and strong earthquakes.

Broader Impact

An anchored viscoelastic layer provides a new distributed damping treatment for earthquake response reduction in civil engineering and vibration suppression in mechanical/civil engineering. Its integration into a multi-layer strengthening system opens a new venue for optical seismic retrofit/repair of RC columns and bridges subjected to multiple earthquakes of varying intensities by increasing column ductility and reducing earthquake loads simultaneously. Although yet to be further developed, the integration of an aerogel (foam) layer in the strengthening system provides a new research direction of making corrosion-free PVC and FRP confined columns to behave in a more ductile manner under earthquake loads. This project resulted in eleven journal publications, at least one conference paper, more than five presentations at professional meetings and conferences, and one Ph.D. dissertation. It provided interdisciplinary training (civil engineering and chemistry) for three Ph.D. students (Mostafa Fakharifar, Chenglin Wu, and Shruti Mahadik-Khanolkar) and short-term civil engineering training for additional two Ph.D. students (Hongya Qu and Tiantian Li) in structural damage assessment. Two out of five Ph.D. students are female.

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2016
Modified by: Genda Chen
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project aims to explore, develop, and apply novel damping-enhanced or hybrid strengthening technologies for the seismic retrofit/repair of reinforced concrete (RC) columns and bridges under earthquake excitations with various intensities. An aerogel (foam) or viscoelastic (VE) layer is integrated into a multi-layer sandwiched system of a polyvinyl-chloride (PVC) tube and fiber reinforced polymer (FRP) sheets. The aerogel/viscoelastic material is used for energy dissipation/impact attenuation while the PVC or FRP layers restrain the lateral expansion of RC columns under axial loads. The performances of the novel technologies are compared with those of FRP wrapping alone and a prestressed thin steel sheet wrapping. The seismic performance of RC columns is translated into the system behavior of a three-span girder bridge with RC columns. Intellectual Merits This project enabled the exploration of several new concepts and methods over the project period. First, polyurea and polyurethane xerogels were characterized as a component of a sandwiched FRP wrapping system for concrete confinement. Although yet to be further developed, the integration of an aerogel (foam) layer in the strengthening system provides a new research direction of making corrosion-free PVC and FRP confined columns to behave in a more ductile manner under earthquake loads. This project resulted in eleven journal publications, at least one conference paper, more than five presentations at professional meetings and conferences, and one Ph.D. dissertation.
